Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation2: A safety audit is scheduled shortly, and minor issues with equipment have already been flagged.
Story: I stared at the family altar, my mother’s gentle voice echoing in my mind: “This year, you must lead the ceremony. It’s your turn to honor our ancestors.” The weight of tradition pressed on my shoulders, the expectation to perform every ritual perfectly, to show respect, to make my family proud. Yet, my phone buzzed with a reminder—tomorrow was the lab’s safety audit. I remembered the cracked beaker, the loose wire on the centrifuge, the checklist I hadn’t finished. As a scientist, I was responsible for the lab’s safety, for the trust my colleagues placed in me. If I didn’t fix those issues, the audit could go badly, and everyone would know I’d let things slide. My heart pounded as I imagined my family’s disappointment if I missed the ceremony, and my supervisor’s stern face if the lab failed inspection. I felt pulled in two directions, each role demanding my full attention, each expectation impossible to ignore. I stood frozen, torn between the call of my family’s past and the responsibility of my scientific present, unsure which part of myself to honor first.
